title: Friday, 9th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Morning!

BE11:05am

Yeah, I know.

BE11:05am

But let's just take this moment.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

No matter your political stripe, please don't miss out on your chance to enjoy the preeminent level of self-own we've just witnessed.

BE11:06am

Savour it. Enjoy it. This, the very definition of the Pyrrhic victory, the foot shooting, the petard hoist and the jacksie kick delivered by Nemesis to Hubris.

BE11:06am

And yeah, I know. I really do.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

There's only so long you can hold these thoughts before the awful reality of a DUP coalition government creeps in and stains the purity of the schadenfreude.

BE11:06am

I mean ....

BE11:06am

https://twitter.com/eucopresident/status/873098422726701056

11:06 am
BE11:07am

We're boned, right! I mean, we were boned yesterday as well, but still ... It's an interesting new type of boned.

BE11:07am

That's where we are, though. That's where we be.

BE11:07am

Can I also highlight, for those who need it, that the sun moved above the yardarm at 11.06am.

11:07 am
undefined
BE11:08am

Hop over to the liveblog for the news recap. http://blogs.ft.co...alcon&desktop=true

BE11:08am

Josh Noble etc working through the night.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

We'll try not to duplicate too much of that, but it's already about 20,000 words long so some duplication is inevitable.

BE11:09am

In markets terms: sterling down FTSE up. Yep, we're doing that again.

BE11:10am

FTSE ahead 0.7% at pixel, been higher but it's just a side effect of cable right now.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Let's focus on the market readthrough. Expect to see "uncertainty" a lot over the next few pages.

BE11:11am

First, have an overview!

BE11:11am

(Jefferies)

11:11 am
BE11:11am

What should equity investors watch? Although the equity markets seems obsessed by the value of sterling, we would highlight the drivers for UK equities post the election are much more eclectic. Firstly, real Gilt yields are plunging providing a strong tailwind for credit markets and for equities (see RHS chart). Almost unseen Gilt historic volatility has climbed to a 26 year high! Secondly, while the markets might pray for a weaker sterling, investors must be aware of the impact of imported inflation on UK real household incomes.

BE11:12am

And another one!

BE11:12am

(Peel Hunt)

11:12 am
BE11:12am

It is impossible to predict how the UK political backdrop may evolve over the next few days and weeks, but we can make some initial judgements about the likely market response. The recent precedent of the Brexit referendum, where many of the immediate share price moves proved to be over-reactions, should be fresh in the mind of investors and may limit the volatility on this occasion. With sterling extending its slide this morning the FTSE 100 is bound to outperform the mid/small caps thanks to the resources stocks and other heavy overseas earners, while the bond proxies (concentrated among the consumer staples) receive further support from 10-year gilt yields down at 1%. Safe dividend-payers retain what were already considerable attractions in this environment. In contrast, the UK domestic consumer plays (eg retail, leisure), real estate and broader financials are likely to come under immediate pressure, and an indiscriminate markdown in those areas should present some opportunities for the brave.

BE11:12am

Regarding the impact on the UK economy, forecasters will be wrestling with the consequences of greater uncertainty. If the reversal in sterling persists, it may add modestly to the upward pressure on inflation, but it feels that the worst of this squeeze on the consumer is already underway; a potentially brighter outlook for wages later this year, as well as the Bank of England remaining in supportive mode for the foreseeable future, will ease the pain. The likely delay of the Brexit negotiations is now the great imponderable; will it dissuade corporates from making investment decisions? We doubt that many management teams were expecting rapid progress towards a resolution with the EU even if the election result was clear-cut, and those judgements will continue to be made on company-specific grounds. There is also a silver lining for exporters in the competitiveness boost if the pound remains under pressure.

BE11:12am

And some cable!

11:12 am
BE11:12am

(ING)

BE11:13am

The failure to secure political stability – and the outcome of a hung parliament – was always going to be the pound’s nightmare scenario. When Theresa May called this election, markets were viewing things through the rosiest of lenses – with hopes that political uncertainty would decrease substantially under a more stable Conservative government. That narrative has been all but dashed. With the two-year Article 50 clock ticking, the passage of time is GBP negative; a working government is needed as soon as possible to avoid a further drop in the pound. The most likely path looks to be a Conservative-led coalition with the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP); while it may not be straightforward given noise over Theresa May possibly standing down, GBP could enjoy a small relief rally on any political clarity. The worst outcome for GBP now is any prolonged political uncertainty and difficulties in forming a working government over the coming days; here we would expect GBP to trade with a 3-4% political risk premium, with GBP/USD falling back to 1.24 and EUR/GBP moving up towards 0.90.

BE11:13am

Gilts!

11:13 am
BE11:13am

(Deutsche Bank.)

BE11:13am

In our assessment of the market impact of various election outcomes, we had argued that a reduced Conservative majority would generate bullish pressure on Gilts, with our previous analysis pointing to a ~10bp rally in 10Y yields from current levels in the initial reaction.
However, significant uncertainty remains and the path of yields from here depends on the extent to which the market focuses on the bullish impact of increased political uncertainty and the potential for a repeat election versus the likelihood of any softening in the approach to Brexit or increased fiscal policy a new government may take.

BE11:13am

The election result sharply increases political uncertainty, with the Conservatives likely to be dependent on an alliance with the DUP (formal or informal) in order to gain a majority. At the same time, the results would suggest a Labour progressive alliance is now mathematically less likely. The sharply reduced Conservative majority means the harder Brexit wing of the Conservatives will remain powerful, potentially limiting the potential for compromise by the UK side in the upcoming negotiations which in turn would increase the risk of a cliff edge or disorderly Brexit.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Another key dynamic will be the outlook for PM May, with potential criticism from within her party over the election result increasing the chance of a leadership challenge which could further increase political uncertainty given the Brexit negotiations are due to begin later this month. In any case, the current likely outcome of a slim Conservative majority would in itself be inherently unstable and increases the probability of another set of elections over the next 12 months.

BE11:14am

Taken together, the increased political uncertainty should lead the market to push back pricing of the first 25bp hike from the BoE from the mid-2019 at present to the first half of 2020, in line with the richest levels seen in advance of the May Inflation Rreport. The slope of the money market curve will likely bull flatten in response given the directionality with the outright front end rally, although here the path of the FX will be a key variable.

BE11:14am

So far, while sterling has weakened overnight the currency has retraced only to levels seen over April. As a result, the pressure on the BoE to act more hawkish due to inflation pass through (which in turn would steepen the money market curve) should be limited for now. Further out the curve, the rise in political uncertainty should keep the term premium depressed. At the same time, the weakening in sterling together with growing momentum towards less fiscal tightening should limit the extent to which the curve can flatten. More dovish pricing at the front end of the curve together with the risk of a lower term premium should be supportive of the 10Y point of the curve, with our previous analysis pointing to a ~10bp rally towards 90bp on 10Y.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

The Conservatives’ election campaigned was centred upon increasing PM May’s majority in order to improve her ability to achieve her vision of a harder Brexit. At the same time, the opposition campaigns (Labour in particular) focused to a large extent on the domestic economy and a perceived backlash against austerity measures and tight fiscal policy.

BE11:14am

As a result, the narrative of the election result, and the extent to which it is seen as a push back against both (a) harder Brexit and (b) austerity will also represent a key driver of longer term price action.

BE11:14am

We would expect the initial price action to be focused on the impact of sharply increased political uncertainty. However, looking further out there is the potential for the vote to lead to a softening in the Brexit stance given the electorate’s rejection of the Conservatives’ policy together with increased push back against increased fiscal tightening. These drivers would be more bearish rates, but in the short term at least the market is likely to focus first on pricing increased political uncertainty as the market digests the formation of the new government together with the potential for new Conservative leadership. This suggests bullish rates price action should dominate initially.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Phew.

BE11:15am

And we should head into sectors as well, yes?

BE11:16am

Every. Single. Analyst. has a sector note out today saying "weak sterling is good/bad (delete as applicable)."

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Utils to begin maybe? Nationalisation slightly more likely?

BE11:17am

HSBC says "nah."

BE11:17am

Despite the uncertainty from a hung parliament we believe that the three interventions set out in the Conservative Manifesto are highly likely to continue. We do not believe that the plans for renationalisation set out by Labour, however, are likely to be enacted.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Three interventions were promised in the Conservative Manifesto which we believe could be supported by a coalition. The first is a review of the cost of energy to industry. We believe that this would be favoured by a coalition as might an industrial energy efficiency scheme to help large companies install measures to cut their energy use and their bills. Offshore wind remains the favoured renewable technology for Conservatives, Labour has reiterated its commitment to nuclear.

BE11:18am

The other two affect the retail market Both the Conservatives and Labour were committed in their manifestos to introduce a safeguard tariff cap that will extend the price protection currently in place for some vulnerable customers to more customers on the poorest value tariffs. The Conservatives in their Manifesto wanted to “maintain the competitive element of the retail energy market by supporting initiatives to make the switching process easier and more reliable, but the safeguard tariff cap will protect customers who do not switch against abusive price increases”. Labour was explicit about a GBP1,000 tariff cap. The third broader consumer area is about “strengthening the powers of consumer enforcement bodies” to order fines against companies breaking consumer law and deliver redress for wronged parties. They intend to explore how to give consumers a voice in the regulation of business. They say they will “consider placing a duty on regulators to weigh up the needs of vulnerable customers”. They also want to “act to make terms and conditions clearer”.

BE11:18am

In our view, utilities should prepare at least for these three areas of intervention which we believe could be enacted. In our discussions with investors there is already familiarity with the extent to which say a GBP100 price cap reduction would affect the supply revenues of Centrica and SSE (cGBP500m and GBP200m) respectively according to the companies. In our conversations with the companies what they need from any new government is a clear and stable trajectory of energy policy to allow them to make good investment decisions. We think the renationalisation of the regulated pipes and wires (regulated assets of GBP83bn, proposed by Labour) is no longer a near-term possibility.

11:18 am
Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 200.70, up 1.9 (+0.96%), High: 206.40, Low: 200.70, Volume: 15.96m
SSE PLC (SSE:LSE): Last: 1,507, up 15 (+1.01%), High: 1,535, Low: 1,506, Volume: 1.98m
United Utilities Group PLC (UU.:LSE): Last: 1,004, up 6.5 (+0.65%), High: 1,015, Low: 997.00, Volume: 1.24m
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Morgan Stanley also.

BE11:18am

1) A proposed tariff cap: This was a Conservative manifesto proposal, with Labour also promising an emergency cap to keep dual-fuel bills below £1,000. Near term governing uncertainty perhaps means this is less of a focus. Any delay is a positive for Centrica and SSE.

BE11:19am

(2) Scotland and another referendum: The reduction in SNP (Scottish National Party) seats could point to a lower risk around a second Scottish Independence referendum. This would be a positive for SSE (and perhaps (less so) for Iberdrola).

11:19 am
BE11:19am

(3) Networks and nationalisation: The Labour manifesto contained a proposal to "regain control" of energy supply networks and transition to a "publicly owned, decentralised energy system"; and a proposal to introduce a network of regional publicly-owned water companies. If Labour is not part of the next government, this likelihood diminishes, positive for UK regulated utilities.

BE11:19am

(4) Sterling: If sterling weakens, this should be a small benefit to Centrica and National Grid, with c.25% and 45% of EBIT coming from US businesses respectively on MSe 2017 forecasts.

National Grid PLC (NG.:LSE): Last: 1,023, up 1.5 (+0.15%), High: 1,037, Low: 1,022, Volume: 3.91m
11:19 am
BE11:20am

Next, maybe the housebuiders?

BE11:20am

Down, though not Brexit down.

Taylor Wimpey PLC (TW.:LSE): Last: 178.60, down 4.9 (-2.67%), High: 180.00, Low: 173.00, Volume: 14.52m
11:20 am
Barratt Developments PLC (BDEV:LSE): Last: 573.50, down 16.5 (-2.80%), High: 583.00, Low: 565.50, Volume: 3.19m
Crest Nicholson Holdings PLC (CRST:LSE): Last: 587.00, down 23.5 (-3.85%), High: 600.00, Low: 569.50, Volume: 2.47m
BE11:21am

Sellside saying, "guys, politicians don't crash the housing market."

11:21 am
BE11:22am

(@Eti, @BlueHorseshoe: there are better places to have this conversation. I'd rather it weren't using our pixels.)

BE11:22am

Here's Canaccord.

BE11:22am

While the outcome of the election creates more uncertainty, we do not expect there to be a severe jolt to share prices and de-rating anywhere near the scale seen post the shock Brexit vote. Sector share prices are essentially where they were at the time the election was called. Valuation-wise they look a bit vulnerable to a period of extended uncertainty. Assuming a minority Conservative government, there are unlikely to be any near-term significant changes to housing policy, which would have been the case if we were to see a Labour-led government. We believe that the biggest impact for the sector is the potential impact the uncertainty will have on consumer confidence and the wider housing market, as well as potentially delaying public and corporate spending in the near term. Overall, the sector is generally in good shape to deal with more uncertainty in the wider economy and political backdrop.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Macro indicators suggest that the wider housing market has stalled over the last few months. A hung parliament is likely to extend a slower market generally into the seasonally quieter summer market and raise more questions over trends into H217 and 2018. However, new build sales have been strong year to date and with a strong spring selling season, we expect a good set of first half results. Balance sheets remain very strong and the cost side is unlikely to be significantly impacted. The key concern is likely to be around how confidence and sales rates trend from here and particularly in the next important selling season during this autumn. Assuming a minority Conservative government, significant policy changes, which would have been the case with a Labour-led government, have been avoided. A minority Conservative government is likely to see broadly more of the same in terms of housing policy, based on the recent White Paper proposals. Overall, the sector remains in good shape to deal with the expected level of uncertainty with strong order books, strong balance sheets and government policy support.

BE11:22am

Clearly, a weakening of consumer confidence and the wider housing market would impact the merchants and materials, and questions about the recent trends are unlikely to go away. Expectations for UK profits are already low with profits expected to be flat to down for 2018-19. Currency impacts are not expected to be significant, as they were post Brexit, with current assumptions in our models of sterling slightly weaker than where it currently is. Balance sheets are generally comfortable and the sector has levers to pull if trading conditions weaken over the coming months. With expectations where they are, the sector looks less vulnerable to significant cuts to earnings but a period of protracted uncertainty will likely keep pressure on the ratings in the near term.

BE11:22am

The sector is very UK-centric and therefore will be under the spotlight. Stocks likely to be supported by their overseas earnings are Wolesley, CRH, Tyman, Volution and SIG. Housebuilders trade on a 2017E P/NAV multiple of c.2 times with the materials stocks on a PE of c.15 times.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

And Jefferies I think was also buying on the way down.

BE11:24am

What happened a year ago? Following the unexpected EU referendum result the UK
housebuilders share prices fell, on average, by around 40%. As markets closed yesterday
the sector was trading broadly where it closed on 23 June 2016. Our take is that even
the uncertainty of Brexit is not enough to undermine the strong fundamentals of the UK
housebuilding industry. Buying on weakness was the brave thing to do last year and luck
favoured the brave then and we expect luck to favour the brave again now.

BE11:24am

Harder or softer Brexit? With an unexpected general election result, we are wary of making predictions about the future hard or softness of Brexit. The truth is we do not know, just as we didn't know on the 24th and 27th of June last year. What we do know is that UK housebuilder share prices over reacted to the Brexit uncertainty and for a while share prices were divorced from the strong fundamentals. If they over react again, we suggest buying the shares again.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

UK Housebuilders buy on weakness: Our top picks are Taylor Wimpey and Berkeley Group. We believe that Taylor Wimpey offers the most attractive cash return profile and most share price upside of the UK major housebuilders. We also would buy Berkeley on weakness as we are very firmly of the view that fears surrounding the London housing market in the light of today's election result will be overdone. The analysis we published last year on cash generation holds true today, should the new build market stall, turning the land buying tap off allows the dividend tap to be kept fully on.

BE11:24am

Help to Buy is likely to continue, in our view, to provide the dividing line between the two speed housing market: new build market good, secondhand market bad. Following the EU referendum UK housebuilders bounced back more quickly than we anticpated.

BE11:25am

UK estate agents further dark days ahead: We expect that the impact of a hung parliament will be to further depress the level of housing transactions and cause more households to defer their home moving plans. There is, however, a silver lining to the housing market cloud however, further tightening in second hand stock levels would, in our view, underpin prices reducing the risk of significant house price falls.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

UK property portals: We continue to believe that the UK Property Portals have the most robust business models of all the stocks we cover. Revenues are one step removed from house prices and transaction levels and ROI for their customers is easy to calculate. On valuation grounds our preference is for ZPG over Rightmove, although we would buy both on weakness.

BE11:25am

UK Construction: A hung parliament does not mean that roads do not need repairing or new power stations built, however, corporate investment may pause for breath once again. Our top picks in UK construction focus on those with exposure to UK new build residential. Morgan Sindall is therefore our top pick

BE11:26am

(I know there's a crazy amount of grey in today's session. Apologies. I was up for much of the night, having accidentally found myself in a Brixton pub that quickly turned into a bit of a party when the exit poll went up.)

11:26 am
BE11:27am

(As a result, cutting and pasting is about as much as I can manage this morning,)

undefined
BE11:27am

Banks next, then?

11:27 am
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 250.20, down 7 (-2.72%), High: 255.00, Low: 246.00, Volume: 12.56m
BE11:28am

Been lower.

Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 69.58, down 1.14 (-1.61%), High: 69.66, Low: 67.00, Volume: 146.42m
11:29 am
BE11:29am

It's mostly a sterling story -- sorry for repeating myself -- though with a lot of longer term noise in there too.

BE11:29am

Here's Citi.

BE11:29am

What Does This Mean For UK Banks? – GBP has fallen by 1.5% and could weaken further if uncertainty prevails. This should support the International UK banks, HSBC & StanChart. Meanwhile gilt yields may rise slightly in this uncertainty, driving higher funding costs (and thereby lower NIMs) and a higher cost of equity for the UK domestic banks, such as Barclays, Lloyds and RBS. Further uncertainty on Brexit negotiations is also likely to weigh on UK loan growth.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Overweight UK International; Underweight UK Domestic Banks – We have Buy ratings on HSBC & StanChart, where improving trade flows and rising US rates, should support volume growth and NIMs respectively. In contrast we have Sell ratings on Barclays, Lloyds and RBS due to UK political & economic uncertainty, subdued UK loan growth, the prospect for declining NIMs on asset margin pressure (with limited ability to flex liability rates any further) and a gradual rise in net loan losses, as house prices stabilize and consumer losses begin to normalize.

BE11:30am

And SocGen too.

BE11:30am

(@pfd: ditto.)

11:30 am
BE11:30am

In its manifesto, the Labour Party accepted Brexit but emphasised the benefits of the Single Market and Customs Union. Labour’s better-than-expected election result will likely be interpreted as a vote for a softer form of Brexit. That may help the market’s economic outlook if implemented but to get to that point would probably require a new Conservative leader. Meanwhile, the Brexit clock is ticking given that Article 50 was triggered earlier this year.

BE11:30am

Uncertainty that comes with a hung parliament is likely to dampen the economy at a time when it’s already slowing, compounded by the extra Brexit uncertainty. The single most important indicator for credit quality for the banks is how quickly unemployment changes. London property prices have already started to fall, and this may now accelerate. Lloyds has most exposure to London mortgages, but its balances have been stable or slightly down in recent years, while RBS has grown quickly in London.

BE11:30am

11:30 am
BE11:30am

The banking sector didn’t really featured in the Conservatives’ campaign. But if the Conservatives now feel compelled to tack toward Labour policies, it will likely be negative for the banks. Labour said it would consult on an RBS break-up and implement a financial transactions tax (projected yield £5bn). It has also flagged moving the general corporate tax rate up to 26% from the Conservatives’ planned 17%. On the other hand, Theresa May hasn’t been exactly business friendly in our view and her weakened position perhaps makes it more likely that Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond remains in post.

BE11:31am

We expect the banks to sell off this morning. That said, HSBC and STAN likely sit above the fray given that most of their profits come from abroad. With another political shock, share price trends since Brexit may be a helpful template – although, to be clear, this is in our view a much less seismic shock and so any moves are likely to be smaller scale. After the Brexit vote, HSBC and STAN were largely unaffected. Barclays sold off initially but recovered in just a matter of months. RBS and LLOY were yesterday back to close to their pre-Brexit levels, a deep underperformance versus the UK market since the pre-referendum price. However, if we look at performance from the close on the first day after the referendum, Lloyds is up 30% and RBS 25% versus the UK market up 26% (all numbers total shareholder returns).

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 695.20, up 10.3 (+1.50%), High: 698.60, Low: 688.40, Volume: 10.85m
11:30 am
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 775.60, up 16.6 (+2.19%), High: 777.80, Low: 761.00, Volume: 3.11m
undefined
BE11:33am

https://twitter.com/George_Osborne/status/873119870862245888

11:33 am
BE11:34am

Hmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm ......................

BE11:04am

BE11:35am

Perhaps George could consider rotating @Adamstoon1 with Brant, Physical Cartoonist from The Day Today.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

I mean, it's not going to get worse.

undefined
BE11:36am

And now, I guess we continue this yomp through the sectors.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Keep talking among yourselves, ROTR, and I'll fill the leftspace somehow.

BE11:37am

Insurance?

Admiral Group PLC (ADM:LSE): Last: 2,066, up 17 (+0.83%), High: 2,068, Low: 2,030, Volume: 132.14k
11:37 am
Standard Life PLC (SL.:LSE): Last: 383.70, down 0.5 (-0.13%), High: 385.10, Low: 379.60, Volume: 1.48m
Direct Line Insurance Group PLC (DLG:LSE): Last: 349.60, up 3.6 (+1.04%), High: 349.65, Low: 340.10, Volume: 1.31m
BE11:37am

Here's UBS.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

In our view, a hung parliament has potential implications in relation to UK motor insurance, which we see as likely to (a) affect the likelihood of amendment to the Ogden rate and/or (b) the likelihood of Whiplash reforms passing through parliament in its current form (Labour has stated that the reform of whiplash claims was "based on a false premise"), we would at least expect further delay to passing revised legislation. Our positive sub-sector view (link to report) was partly predicated on these reforms passing. In terms of UK exposure (noting potential currency / interest rate movements), the following insurers have greater than 5% of group operating profit from the UK: Admiral, Direct Line, Saga, St James Place, Hastings, esure (c100%), Standard Life, L&G (c95%), Aviva (55%), Hiscox (c35%), RSA, Prudential (c25%), Lancashire (c20%), Ageas, Beazely, Hannover Re, Munich Re, SCOR, Swiss Re (less than 10%).

undefined
BE11:38am

Holy h*ck! A reader mentioned a stock!

11:38 am
Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 967.00, down 20.5 (-2.08%), High: 970.00, Low: 954.50, Volume: 4.39m
BE11:39am

So clearly, there's a lot of arb money in here, which means the risk-reward of Ofcom is being analysed in atomic detail.

BE11:40am

Ofcom's due to do its thing on the Fox/Sky deal on 20 June

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Issues of media plurality, broadcasting standards and the 'fit and proper' test to be delivered to the Secretary of State for Culture Media and Sport, whoever that might be.

BE11:41am

And there's no obligation on Ofcom to make its recommendations public, interestingly enough.

BE11:41am

Here's UBS to say it's probably still on.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

We think potential regulatory hurdles could be overcome but there is the potential for Ofcom to apply caveats around the extent of some of its findings given the relatively short period of time it had to review the deal. The Secretary of State is not bound to follow Ofcom's recommendation. Had the Conservatives won a large majority, we think it would have been more straightforward to approve the deal relatively quickly but as we have discussed earlier (please see link above) we note that Labour MPs have been vocal in their opposition to the Fox/Sky deal. With the Conservatives remaining the largest party, we still see scope for the deal to be approved but the risks around an extended review have increased with potential for the deal to go to an in depth review with the CMA or lengthy discussions with the Secretary of State over remedies/undertakings

BE11:42am

In terms of potential remedies, should the issues arise we continue to think Fox could re-visit a spin-off of Sky News, as it did with the original bid for Sky in 2010/11. Separately, James Murdoch could step down as Chairman of Sky, but remain CEO of Fox.

BE11:42am

We remain fundamentally positive on Sky and re-iterate our view that operational gearing into 2018E has been underestimated. However, approval for the Fox/Sky deal is likely to be the main driver of the share price and an extended review would likely constrain the share price in the near-term. As a result, we remove Sky from our Key Call list but retain our Buy rating and 1310p price target based on our longer-term view.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

And RBC.

BE11:42am

Assuming a CON/DUP minority government, we would expect last night’s spread of c.8% to widen slightly reflecting heightened risk until the 20th June report.
Assuming a Conservative Sec. of State, and a benign Ofcom report, we still expect approval. Post 20th June, an approval would lead to the risk arb spread likely tightening to c.3-4% (ie. £10.30-£10.40 vs £10.75 offer). A referral of the deal to the CMA would lead to a widening to c.15% (c. £9.15) in our view. A rejection (or a Labour-led coalition) would result in Sky trading as a ‘broken deal’, and we see 800p as a likely floor.

BE11:43am

Though, as @Fatdaz observes, media weak across the board today.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Because they're UK economy plays with not much in overseas earnings, mostly.

BE11:43am

Citi with the sector wrap.

BE11:44am

The media names most exposed to the UK are RMV, ZPG, AUTO, TNI, ITV, SKY and DMGT, of which ITV, DMGT and TNI are most cyclically exposed via UK advertising. RMV is a pure play in the UK housing market and greater uncertainty is likely to lead to downwards pressure. We expect all of these names to face a bigger impact today given the high UK exposure.
Any weakness in GBP could provide support for GBP reporting stocks with limited UK exposure such as PSON, WPP, RELX, UBM and INF. All of these names have less than 15% exposure to the UK. The stocks with limited to no exposure to the UK tend to be the domestic FTA broadcasters as well as Stroeer and Schibsted.
We continue to prefer names with global exposure and strong FCF, and in that context WPP, PUBP, SES and UBM remain our top picks.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 183.00, down 3.2 (-1.72%), High: 183.10, Low: 178.50, Volume: 13.96m
Daily Mail and General Trust (DMGT:LSE): Last: 647.00, down 5 (-0.77%), High: 651.50, Low: 644.00, Volume: 231.30k

DX (Group) plc

("DX" or the "Company")

Investigation by the City of London Police

The Board of DX announces that it has been notified by the City of London Police Economic Crime Directorate ("City of London Police") of an allegation that has been made against the Company which has resulted in the commencement of a preliminary investigation centred on the DX Exchange operations.

The investigation is at a very early stage. The Board of DX received the details of the allegation on 7 June 2017 and is co-operating fully with the City of London Police.

A further announcement will be made when appropriate.

The initially envisaged terms of the Transaction have been revised. As such, it is envisaged that DX would acquire Menzies Distribution on a cash and debt free basis, comprising £40m (previously £60m) in cash and the issue of new DX shares representing 65% (previously 80%) of DX's issued capital as enlarged by the Transaction. We provide further details of these revisions within this note and the impact on the proposed full ownership structure of the Enlarged Group.

undefined
BE12:02pm

Okay, it's midday. But just for the sake of completeness, let's chuck up some more sector stuff.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Stifel on retail!

BE12:03pm

With the general retail sector index highly correlated to the $/£ rate (c.93% in last c.2 years to mid-May) a large Conservative majority would have been the ideal outcome, with “just” the Brexit negotiations to complete led by a solid pro-corporate government with a five-year mandate. Today’s muddled hung parliament outcome leaves sterling initially weaker ($1.27), the EU’s negotiating stance potentially emboldened and international corporates more likely to consider alternative European bases to the UK. On this morning’s evidence, this electoral outcome reduces the likelihood of an early end to the (weak sterling driven) inflationary squeeze on disposable incomes and higher UK retailers’ import costs. In effect, potentially more of the UK general retail sector underperformance of the last 18 months. The alternative (less negative) view would be a potentially softer Brexit outcome which might upset some voters but might be more reassuring to the corporates.

BE12:03pm

In terms of stock picks, the sector (relative) outperformers in the 12 months to end-February (prior to sterling rally to $1.30) were Boohoo, Supergroup, Findel, WH Smith and Kingfisher; generally a group with higher non-UK sales & EBIT and/or defensive attractions. In terms of short-term underperformers, recent rallies in M&S and Next look vulnerable.

12:03 pm

Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 357.40, down 9.3 (-2.54%), High: 362.30, Low: 353.30, Volume: 4.52m

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

RBC on ....... uh, healthcare?

BE12:03pm

With a hung parliament likely leading to more moderate policy changes we see a potential benefit to UK healthcare spend, but the UK is a small fraction of the global market so not as relevant as say the US. Hence minimal overall impact to our coverage. No impact from minimum wage changes to our coverage. Corporation tax rates change, albeit some don’t pay tax..., but of those that do higher tax is negative for Consort, Clinigen, ConvaTec, Dechra and Vectura as each have a larger UK operation than Abcam, BTG and Indivior (smaller negative).
The largest impact is on FX – which will more than offset tax changes, given most names are such large overseas earners. GBP weakening is a particular positive for Abcam, BTG and Dechra albeit most names will benefit.
We see another unknown in the Brexit negotiations, and how this could impact cross-border drug approvals, taxation etc., and believe this risk factor has increased now we find ourselves with a hung parliament. Our view remains that the UK would adopt EMA regulation but potential future tax changes are difficult to predict.

12:03 pm

BE12:04pm

Stifel on North Sea oil!

BE12:04pm

The Scottish National Party losing 20 of 56 seats at the UK General Election is being interpreted as a lack of enthusiasm in Scotland for the cause of Scottish Independence. SNP seats were lost to all the other main parties – Conservatives 12, Labour 6 and Lib Dems 2 – and their vote share decreased by 13.1%.
In a global sector otherwise largely unaffected by UK politics, we would therefore highlight by the North Sea companies from our coverage as key beneficiaries of the election result: Cairn Energy (Buy, Select list stock), Hurricane Energy (Buy, Top Pick) and Premier Oil (Buy). EnQuest (not covered) is also an E&P with principal operations in the UK.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

The logic is twofold:
• Firstly, UK oil & gas tax rates are extremely favourable at present versus other developed market jurisdictions (30% ring-fenced corporation tax + 10% supplementary charge, 62.5% uplift on capex deductible against the SC). Given an independent Scotland's greater budgetary dependence on the oil sector, it is likely (if not a certainty) that devolution to Holyrood would likely lead to more rather than less onerous fiscal conditions.
• There is also a secondary effect from weaker Sterling: this selectively reduces the USD cost base of companies with substantial UK operations.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

RBC on outsourcers!

BE12:05pm

The uncertainty and potential lack of decision-making is a clear negative for the outsourcers (Capita, Carillion, Mitie, Serco). A similar impact is likely to be seen with the staffers, where uncertainty is likely to lead to a lack of decision-making by corporates – Hays and PageGroup have the biggest UK exposure. Travis Perkins is also likely to see a negative impact (uncertainty, consumer, decision-making), whilst weaker sterling would increase product price inflation.
Weaker sterling, however, is a positive for many companies in the sector from a translation perspective, given significant overseas exposure.

BE12:08pm

Cazenove, slightly sector-y.

BE12:08pm

 Implications for Brexit: According to our UK economists, given the path that the May administration had taken was toward a ‘hard’ Brexit, it is difficult to see the election result generating explicit policy decisions on the UK side which would make Brexit appear ‘harder’. But the ability for the UK to sustain political continuity through the discussions looks challenged. Perhaps the most obvious conclusion is that the likelihood of the UK needing to request a delay in the Brexit process has risen substantially, given the chance that political developments in the UK disturb what is already a time-compressed process.
 Reduced support for SNP and Scottish Independence: One of the early outcomes is the decline in the SNP’s seats, which is likely to be much larger than expected. The SNP appears to have suffered from tactical voting in favor of Unionist parties and the result will widely be seen as a rejection of the SNP pressure for a second independence referendum. This bodes positively for the domestic UK banks, with CYBG having the highest exposure to Scotland at 16% of loans followed by Lloyds and RBS at sub 10%.

12:09 pm
BE12:09pm

And CLSA buying the dip on Clydesdale.

BE12:10pm

Despite the likely continued uncertainty and potentially weak
business/consumer sentiment in the short term, we remain confident on the overall strength of the UK economy. Furthermore, we remain confident on CYB’s ability to continue to perform. The UK regulator is pro-growth and once a government is formed it will likely do everything in its power to support the economy. Trading on FY18CL 0.82x BV and 12.3x PE with EPS growth of 18.9%, CYB offers not only value but growth relative to an expensive Australian market. We continue to believe CYB has an above system growth outlook (plenty of latency in the current operating model), a great cost out story, strong balance sheet and capital position with leverage in achieving advanced accreditation. We maintain our BUY recommendation.

BE12:10pm

Key investment thematics
1. The UK election creates some more unwanted political/economic uncertainty. This noise will likely be maintained in the short term but we remain confident on the overall strength of the UK economy.
2. Earnings outlook remains positive. Management reiterated guidance at 1H17 with momentum building (2Q17 stronger than 1Q17). NIM and costs likely above management expectations. The next data point, 3Q17 trading update, is due out on 27 July.
3. Capital tailwinds. CYB has leverage to the PRA lowering standardised mortgage risk weights and achieving advanced accreditation. We see CYB holding around 65p per share in excess capital once advanced accreditation is achieved.
4. UK economy and Brexit. While the economy continues to perform above expectations, the next couple of years will likely be somewhat volatile.
5. M&A opportunities remain for CYBG.
6. CYB a value play with growth.
